dc:description:
*KCNH2* was first reported in relation to Brugada syndrome in 2005 (Verkerk, et al. PMID: 16043162). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data. Of note, this gene has previously been assessed for Long QT Syndrome.

Two missense variants reported in two probands affected by Brugada syndrome from one publication were included in this curation (PMID: 39895654). Family segregation evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship was not found in the literature. Additional reported individuals with *KCNH2 *variants were not considered for this curation (PMIDs: 16043162, 18692916, 38648771) because the phenotypic specificity and associated patch clamp data were insufficient to support an association with Brugada syndrome, as determined by the ClinGen Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease GCEP. 

Bulk tissue gene expression data shows ubiquitous expression of *KCNH2* in human tissues, including the heart (PMID: 23715323, GTex dbGaP Accession phs000424.v10.p2). However, mice and cell culture rescue models for KCNH2 did not recapitulate the Brugada phenotype observed in human patients nor the gain of function disease mechanism indicative of Brugada syndrome (PMIDs: 12612061, 21536673). 

In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between *KCNH2* and autosomal dominant Brugada syndrome has been disputed and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role *KCNH2* plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease GCEP on June 10th 2025 (SOP Version 11).
curationReasonDescription: There is weak case-level evidence with poor phenotype specificity in reported probands to support the KCNH2-Brugada syndrome relationship. Available functional data not did not recapitulate the phenotype observed in human patients nor the gain-of-function disease mechanism. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role KCNH2 plays in this disease.

evidence.dc:description: As per HCVD EP, this mouse model displayed bradycardia but did not mimic Brugada phenotype observed in humans. Experimental data did not demonstrate gain of function disease mechanism related to Brugada syndrome.
Deletion of ERG1 B from mice removes the fast component of IKr. In fetal ERG1 B−/− murine ventricle, the slow component of IKr is intact and IKs is upregulated.
evidence.rdfs:label: ERG1 knock out mice

evidence.dc:description: Experimental data is not specific to gain of function disease mechanism of Brugada syndrome. Rescue is for loss of function and does not recapitulate Brugada phenotype.

evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of gating deficiencies in KCNH2

evidence.dc:description: Bulk tissue gene expression for KCNH2 shows ubiquitous expression in human tissues, including the heart.
evidence.rdfs:label: GTex

evidence.dc:description: Score of 0. As per HCVD EP, the patient's phenotype and patch clamp data deemed insufficient to support Brugada association. Showed gain-of-function changes, more consistent with Short QT than Brugada. ECG phenotypes either did not support Brugada or were inconclusive.
The R1135H mutant expressed functional channels in CHO cells with apparently slowed and larger tail currents.

Score of 0. As per HCVD EP, patch clamp data deemed insufficient to support Brugada pattern. They showed gain-of-function changes, more consistent with Short QT than Brugada. ECG phenotypes either did not support Brugada or were inconclusive.
HEK cells transfected with KCNH2-R397C plasmid have facilitated activation of the HERG channels, and hampered their inactivation, suggesting that p.R397C is a gain-of-function mutation

Score of 0. As per HCVD EP, the patient's phenotype and patch clamp data deemed insufficient to support Brugada association. Variant N985S functional data is similar to a Likely benign/benign variant G873S and noted as modifier variant by author.

Patch-clamp experiments revealed both variants produced an increased IKr current density and a  negative shift of inactivation leading to increased rectification compared to wildtype. Variant protein, however, increased Ipeak during the AP upstroke.
